name: Current and Circuits
readingPassage:
Currents & Circuits

Electric circuits involve several interconnected concepts that describe how charges move and interact in conductors.

Potential Difference

The potential difference between two points is the work done per unit charge to move a charge from one point to another. It is defined by $!$ V = \frac{W}{q} $!$ and measured in volts (V). Releasing a charge at a point with high potential energy results in kinetic energy gain equal to $!$ qV $!$.

Electric Current

Electric current is the rate at which charge flows through a conductor. It is given by $!$ I = \frac{\Delta q}{\Delta t} $!$ and measured in amperes (A), where 1 A equals 1 coulomb per second.

Electric Resistance and Resistivity

Resistance is the opposition a conductor offers to the flow of charge and is expressed by $!$ R = \frac{V}{I} $!$. According to Ohm's law, at constant temperature, the current through a conductor is proportional to the potential difference, or $!$ I \propto V $!$. Experiments show that a conductor's resistance depends on its physical properties: length, cross-sectional area, and the nature of its material. This relationship is captured by the resistivity formula: $!$ R = \frac{\rho L}{A} $!$, where $!$ \rho $!$ is the resistivity.

Microscopic View of Resistance

On a microscopic level, resistance occurs because free electrons in a conductor, which move randomly at high speeds, suffer collisions with atoms. These inelastic collisions transfer energy to the atoms, causing vibrations (i.e., increased temperature), which in turn increases resistance.

Resistors in Circuits

Resistors can be combined in series or parallel to control the overall resistance. In series, resistances add directly: $!$ R_{\text{total}} = R_1 + R_2 + \dots $!$. In parallel, they combine as $!$ \frac{1}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \dots $!$, resulting in a total resistance smaller than any individual resistance.

Electric Power

Electric power is the rate of energy conversion or work done. In a circuit component like a resistor, power is given by $!$ P = VI $!$, which is dissipated as heat or used to perform work.

Measuring Instruments

An ammeter is used to measure current and is connected in series, ideally having zero resistance to not affect the circuit. A voltmeter measures potential difference and is connected in parallel with the component, ideally exhibiting infinite resistance.

Electromotive Force (emf) and Internal Resistance

A cell or battery supplies an electromotive force (emf), the work done per unit charge as it moves charge from one terminal to the other, defined by $!$ \varepsilon = \frac{W}{q} $!$. Due to internal chemical processes, real cells have an internal resistance $!$ r $!$. Thus, with current $!$ I $!$ flowing, the terminal voltage is reduced to $!$ V = \varepsilon - Ir $!$.

Potential Dividers

A potential divider (or potentiometer) uses a continuous resistor (or a wire) with a movable contact (slider) to generate a variable output voltage. By adjusting the connection point along the resistor, a user can obtain a voltage ranging from 0 V to the full emf of the battery, making it useful for calibrating and testing other devices.

This overview integrates the key concepts of electric potential, current, resistance (including resistivity), circuit configurations, power, measurement techniques, and the practical aspects of real batteries.
